response:
<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: for(Iterator<DataSnapshot> it = dataSnapshot.getChildren().iterator(); it.hasNext(); ){
i = i + 1;
names.add(it.next().getValue(String.class));
}
<<<explanation>>>: You're creating a new dataSnapshot.getChildren().iterator() in every iteration of your loop. Try to just use the value of the foreach inside the loop.

For your second question, you can use a HashSet to keep track of the numbers that appear in each list. Here's an example of how you can do it:

<<<api>>>: HashSet
<<<code>>>: for(Iterator<DataSnapshot> it = dataSnapshot.getChildren().iterator(); it.hasNext(); ){
if(it.next().getValue(Integer.class) != null) {
HashSet<Integer> numbers = new HashSet<>();
numbers.add(it.next().getValue(Integer.class));
}
}
<<<explanation>>>: Iterate through each ArrayList and put all the values into a HashSet. If the value is not null, add it to the HashSet. Finally, you can iterate through the HashSet and perform ArrayList.contains() to check if the number appears in any of the lists. If none of the ArrayLists return false for the operation, add the number to a "master list" which contains all the final values.
